prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity: These are both line and continuum observations, with the line rms being the most limiting. LINES: Figure 4 shows a sample SMA spectrum from one of the brighter CH3CN line sources in our sample with 3.4" (~10000 AU at 3 kpc) angular resolution, 1.1 km/s spectral resolution, and an rms noise of 0.2 K. Our goal is to achieve the same rms noise with our ALMA observations but with 3x higher angular and spectral resolution. The increase in angular resolution is required to resolve the protocluster members with expected separations of >5000 AU and the increase in spectral resolution is required to accurately trace the kinematics of the circumprotostellar environments in lines that are ~ 3 km/s wide. The peak intensities of the CH3CN K=2 transition range from 0.5 to 4.4 K in the SMA data across the sample. Accounting for the probable beam dilution of the SMA data we expect the 1.1" ALMA data to have peak intensities about 9x higher or 4.5 to 40 K. Thus the maximum expected dynamic range in the lines will be about 200, easily achievable. With an rms noise of 0.2 K, angular resolution of 1.1" and a spectral resolution of 244 kHz (0.33 km/s) the required time-on-source is only 3.64 min per pointing. In order to cover most of the FOV available for the proposed Band 3 observations ~68" (to measure SEDs), we are using a 7-pt mosaic with 0.7 FWHP spacing which produces nearly uniform sensitivity over the mapped region (i.e. similar to that used for the NVSS survey). With overheads, each of the six targets takes about 1 hour. CONTINUUM: With the parameters described above and an estimated continuum bandwidth of 4 GHz, the continuum sensitivity will be about 95 microJy/beam, sufficient to detect intermediate to massive protostellar dust sources, and constrain the presence and nature of of free-free emission from jets or HCHII regions (Fig. 3).
Imaging: The main science goals for the Band 6 data relate to resolving and characterizing the individual protocluster members, thus the spatial frequency range from 1.1" to a LAS of 10" (3300 to 30000 AU at 3 kpc) delivered by a single 12m-configuration is adequate (see Fig. 2). Note: there ar some outflow tracers in the Band 6 setup but the key ones are in the Band 3 setup which has an LAS almost 3x larger. Other considerations for this topic were already covered in the sensitivity section.
Correlator Setup: We are using all 4 basebands with dual polarization. The two lower basebands use a single FDM spw with a BW of 469 MHz and a spectral resolution of 244 kHz (0.33 km/s) to cover the key spectral lines labeled on Fig. 4. The upper two basebands are intended primarily for continuum. We have used the 1.3 mm line survey of SgrB2 by Nummelin et al. (1998, ApJS, 117, 427) to place the two USB basebands in as line-free regions as possible. However, we do expect some contamination due to the presence of hot core lines throughout Band 6. Therefore, we have elected to use 1875 MHz FDM spws with 4 channel averaging (for 2.5 km/s resolution) so that we can remove strong lines, while minimizing the data rate.
Calibration: We do not require any unusual calibration.
Scheduling contraints: none
Data rate: The Band 6 data rate is 13.59 MB/s but we have done everything practical to reduce this within the confines of the science goals (see discussion above of required lines, spectral resolution, and the need for line removal from the continuum).

Note: there ar some outflow tracers in the Band 6 setup but the key ones are in the Band 3 setup which has an LAS almost 3x larger. Other considerations for this topic were already covered in the sensitivity section.

The two lower basebands use a single FDM spw with a BW of 469 MHz and a spectral resolution of 244 kHz (0.33 km/s) to cover the key spectral lines labeled on Fig. 4. The upper two basebands are intended primarily for continuum. We have used the 1.3 mm line survey of SgrB2 by Nummelin et al. (1998, ApJS, 117, 427) to place the two USB basebands in as line-free regions as possible. However, we do expect some contamination due to the presence of hot core lines throughout Band 6. Therefore, we have elected to use 1875 MHz FDM spws with 4 channel averaging (for 2.5 km/s resolution) so that we can remove strong lines, while minimizing the data rate.
Calibration: We do not require any unusual calibration.
Scheduling contraints: none
Data rate: The Band 6 data rate is 13.59 MB/s but we have done everything practical to reduce this within the confines of the science goals (see discussion above of required lines, spectral resolution, and the need for line removal from the continuum).

Sensitivity: These are both line and continuum observations, with the continuum rms being the most limiting. CONTINUUM: The requested rms noise of 0.05 mJy/beam (1.1") in an estimated 4 GHz worth of continuum BW is required to detect or constrain the presence of hypercompact HII regions (see Fig. 3) and/or low mass dust continuum sources. If the continuum emission is smoothly distributed on sizescales smaller than our current SMA resolution of 2.3" to 3.4", and the dust spectral index is 4 (both pessimistic assumptions) we expect the 3mm continuum peaks to be between 0.4 to 2.7 mJy/beam for a S/N between 8-50. LINE: With 122 kHz resolution (0.42 km/s) and 7.6 min on source, the spectral rms noise will be about 1.2 K (9 mJy/beam). We expect the 3mm lines to be somewhat optically thick and to range from about 10-100 K. To detect the line wings of the outflow tracers we will spectrally average the data offline.
Imaging: At Band 3 the central portions of the protoclusters are well covered by a single pointing (see Fig. 1). The largest angular scale of 28" (0.4 pc) was chosen based on the NH3 (1,1) morphology (Fig. 1), and prior experience with the outflow structures of similar sources. The angular resolution of 1.1" is required to resolve the protocluster members. The combination of 1.1" angular resolution with this LAS requires both a compact and extended 12m configuration. We do not need ACA or TP. The dynamic range of the continuum and line data is unlikely to exceed 100.
Correlator Setup: We are using all 4 basebands with dual polarization. The two upper basebands have TDM spectral windows to optimize the continuum sensitivity. We have used the 3mm Orion-KL spectral line survey of Turner (1989, ApJS, 70, 539) to select the most line-free regions of the upper sideband to use as continuum. The two lower basebands have 2x117 MHz and 4x58 MHz spws, respectively. This setup lets us get both dense gas and outflow tracers simultaneously, while achieving adequate spectral resolution (~0.42 km/s). The primary lines of interest are: HCO+, H13CO+, HCN, H13CN (all 1-0), and SiO (2-1). The two primary outflow tracers HCO+ and SiO are both in windows with ~400 km/s wide BW which will be plenty.
Calibration: We do not require any unusual calibration.
Scheduling contraints: none
Data rate: The Band 3 science goals are under the 12 MB/s limit.

Sensitivity: These are both line and continuum observations, with the continuum rms being the most limiting. CONTINUUM: The requested rms noise of 0.05 mJy/beam (1.1") in an estimated 4 GHz worth of continuum BW is required to detect or constrain the presence of hypercompact HII regions (see Fig. 3) and/or low mass dust continuum sources. If the continuum emission is smoothly distributed on sizescales smaller than our current SMA resolution of 2.3" to 3.4", and the dust spectral index is 4 (both pessimistic assumptions) we expect the 3mm continuum peaks to be between 0.4 to 2.7 mJy/beam for a S/N between 8-50. Correlator Setup: We are using all 4 basebands with dual polarization. The two upper basebands have TDM spectral windows to optimize the continuum sensitivity. We have used the 3mm Orion-KL spectral line survey of Turner (1989, ApJS, 70, 539) to select the most line-free regions of the upper sideband to use as continuum. The two lower basebands have 2x117 MHz and 4x58 MHz spws, respectively. The primary lines of interest are: HCO+, H13CO+, HCN, H13CN (all 1-0), and SiO (2-1). The two primary outflow tracers HCO+ and SiO are both in windows with ~400 km/s wide BW which will be plenty.
Calibration: We do not require any unusual calibration.
Scheduling contraints: none
Data rate: The Band 3 science goals are under the 12 MB/s limit.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3 G10.34 G14.33 G14.63
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: First 3 sources which are within 10 deg.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity: These are both line and continuum observations, with the continuum rms being the most limiting. CONTINUUM: The requested rms noise of 0.05 mJy/beam (1.1") in an estimated 4 GHz worth of continuum BW is required to detect or constrain the presence of hypercompact HII regions (see Fig. 3) and/or low mass dust continuum sources. If the continuum emission is smoothly distributed on sizescales smaller than our current SMA resolution of 2.3" to 3.4", and the dust spectral index is 4 (both pessimistic assumptions) we expect the 3mm continuum peaks to be between 0.4 to 2.7 mJy/beam for a S/N between 8-50. The largest angular scale of 28" (0.4 pc) was chosen based on the NH3 (1,1) morphology (Fig. 1), and prior experience with the outflow structures of similar sources. The angular resolution of 1.1" is required to resolve the protocluster members. The combination of 1.1" angular resolution with this LAS requires both a compact and extended 12m configuration. We do not need ACA or TP. The dynamic range of the continuum and line data is unlikely to exceed 100.

The two lower basebands have 2x117 MHz and 4x58 MHz spws, respectively. The primary lines of interest are: HCO+, H13CO+, HCN, H13CN (all 1-0), and SiO (2-1). The two primary outflow tracers HCO+ and SiO are both in windows with ~400 km/s wide BW which will be plenty.

Scheduling contraints: none
Data rate: The Band 3 science goals are under the 12 MB/s limit.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Current theories and simulations of massive star formation and hence cluster formation are hampered by a lack of observational data on the physical conditions of the earliest stages. We propose a detailed census of six nearby actively forming young massive "protoclusters" using the unprecedented millimeter sensitivity and imaging fidelity of ALMA. The targets are drawn from our recently-completed SMA and VLA surveys of active massive young stellar objects. By obtaining matched resolution 1.1" images resolution in both bands, we will be able to quantify three major characteristics of these objects. First, we will identify the number of bipolar outflows, locate the protostars driving them, and quantify the current level of energy impact on the cluster. Second, we will measure the number density, mass function, and distribution of the dust cores surrounding individual protostars and any hypercompact HII regions that have escaped noticed in lower frequency centimeter observations. Finally, using hot core molecular lines, we will measure the velocity dispersion of the cluster members to determine the binding energy of the cluster.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
School of Physics and Astronomy, St. Andrews, University of
